results.definition: the main tower within the walls of a medieval castle or fortress

examples: keep a diary
keep notes

results.definition: conform one's action or practice to
examples: keep appointments
she never keeps her promises

results.definition: continue a certain state, condition, or activity
maintain in safety from injury, harm, or danger
examples: May God keep you

results.definition: the financial means whereby one lives
examples: each child was expected to pay for their keep

results.definition: behave as expected during of holidays or rites
prevent the action or expression of
examples: keep your cool

results.definition: stop (someone or something) from doing something or being in a certain state

examples: Can I keep my old stuffed animals?
There's little to earn and many to keep
keep count
I cannot keep track of all my employees
keep my job for me while I give birth
keep my seat, please
keep open the possibility of a merger
These potatoes keep for a long time

results.definition: a cell in a jail or prison

examples: keep potatoes fresh

results.definition: cause to continue in a certain state, position, or activity; e.g., `keep clean'
examples: The students keep me on my toes
I keep a car in the countryside
She keeps an apartment in Paris for her shopping trips

results.definition: allow to remain in a place or position or maintain a property or feature
examples: The family's fortune waned and they could not keep their household staff
Our grant has run out and we cannot keep you on
I always keep batteries in the freezer
keep food for a week in the pantry
She keeps a sixpack and a week's worth of supplies in the refrigerator

results.definition: look after; be the keeper of; have charge of
examples: He keeps the shop when I am gone
She keeps a few chickens in the yard
he keeps bees
Where do you keep your gardening tools?
He is keeping three women in the guest cottage
keep boarders
